reviewText:
Anyone interested in the new Indian motorcycles will want to own this disc, if for nothing else the images of original bikes.
The archival film footage alone is worth the price. I could watch hours of the black and white celluloid with all of the grain, pops and flashes.
The bikes and owners are interesting to see and listen to; these gentlemen have been around the park a few times on their machines.
I'll revisit this CD from time to time then pass it along to other enthusiast.
Interesting old videos and interviews of rough & tumble Indian riders.

Priceless movie with some of the old school "Indians" who made this motorcycle one of the all-time great American success stories. This classic clip features Irenee duPont, whose uncle Paul owned the company.

It does not matter if you are an indian guy or a harley guy, this is a great dvd. i have no problem rewatching this, there are few that i do that with. i recommend this to anyone with an old spirit  who love to own and ride  vintage machines.
I really enjoyed this movie!
Great "old school" DVD about Indian motorcycles and the real bikers who rode them.

This is an incredible documentary with inteviews with many of the great people who were involved with Indian during it's Golden Age. Many who are no longer with us. Thank you for making and sharing this incredible film for future generations to see, and learn from. And for re-releasing it on DVD. Now I can finally get rid of my VCR!
I have watched it a dozen times and I still love it.
If you have an interest in Indian motorcycles, and you haven't seen it, you don't know what your missing!
An amazing piece of American Motorcycle History.
Old footage. Just ok.
Great Video on the history of Indian Motorcycle.

Not bad if this is a home video production. The video quality is a 0 not sure if the camera was always out of focus or watching something that was recorded in the 1980's. Back of the DVD case shows 2013 so I was expecting better quality video. The aspect ratio is off, and video suffers from interlacing at time. Sound levels jump and the audio/video does not flow. This looks like a high school student did the filming and editing.

The only redeeming part of this film it the stories told by the old timers.
Indian Motorcycle riders type of video.
father-in-law loved it

I love indian motorcycle and looked forward to watching this documentary.  I know it was made over twenty years ago but its poor quality for then.  The stories from the older guys were good, but the bad interview skills of the filmmaker made it not flow.  And don't get me started on the background music....jezzzz!
Cool story but poor quality. Seems like an 1980s Vhs copy
My Grandpa Vito "Sunny" Colavito is in this. I can't wait to watch him. He passed in 06'. Miss him and his Indians
Must have for vintage Indian guys

Disliked the show. It was an amature production and for people who know about Indian motorcycles the indian summer refers to the totally victorious 1911 Isle of Mann TT. This dvd has nothing to do with this event which left me totally disappointed.
Nice
Just great!
Great summary of Indian Motorcycle from owners perspective.  Done like a film majors project instead of a historical piece
Made a great gift
Excellent!

Despite fast and prompt delivery, the film is way over priced. It was done in 1994 with very bad audio and even corney and inappropriate music that doesn't fit the "vintage" scenes. It was good to see the old bikes but the video as is should sell for no more that $5.99 in my opinion.
Was not as good as expected!!!

Kind of a hodge podge of facts, old pictures and film with some actual peoples stories.  Kind of a low cost production from maybe the early 70's.

Worth watching on a rainy day and appreciate those who are passionate about motorcycles, especially Indians.
Not only was this a great DVD for motorcycle enthusiast, it came super fast.
Very slow doc. has good history
Good history
Very informative documentary, especially for a bike enthusiast. Well done and an important part of the Indian Motorcycle mystique.
Poorly scripted, disjointed somewhat hard to follow collection of interviews with rather  poor photography. Not owning an Indian, I wondered why I bothered. Don't know if I finished it. Boring!
See and hear about historic Indian motorcycles from owner/collectors
Great entertaining

this is not a high dollar production film.  It is clearly a work of passion and provides some insight into Indian's history that I had not heard before.  If you are into motorcycles, this is worth the price.
loved the movie - perfect gift
Needs a better description as it is vintage stuff which love but others may not.
Who could not love this movie. I'm a big fan of anthony hopkins.its a great and humerous at times movie I highly recommend it.

I beg to differ with the other review--which I read in advance of the purchase.
This attempt at a "movie"--which is really shot like some rinky-dink home video project is amazing in its horrible production quality.  There MAY be some interesting bits of information here, but after 20 minutes, I couldn't take it any more.

I threw it away-I'd hate to give it to someone else for them to dislike as well.

Really a waste of money.  Consider yourself warned.
Haven't seen it yet ... but sounds gound
Great movie, now understand its a low budget documentary.  Its well done very factual.

Sure, if you can get past the home video style, you're in for a treat of a colorful cast of old timers (Doc, Brownie, Whitey, Butch...)  who talk  about and display their vintage Indians, while wonderful background of music by a group called Needles plays in the background. So good was the music, that I looked for the songs on iTunes, but sadly, they're not there.  This movie covers the history of the Indian motorcycle, and is explained lovingly by guys who as old as 89 years old who are owners and fans of Indian.  The filmmaker traveled all over the U.S. interviewing Indian experts and aficionados, and covered speed racing, dirt bike racing, and of course, includes the bike's mechanics.  By the end, I felt like family.

Keep in mind as you view this video it is a true time capsule. Never to be meant as an Oscar winning film..what these two people did back in the 90s (more than likely unknowingly) was to record the last remaining history of the Indian legacy. ..if you love indian 1901-1953 this is a must have part of your library. ...
The production talked to some very important people in Indian's history, but don't expect it to be a great view.

I was somewhat apprehensive about this purchase, having read a few negative reviews on line regarding production quality, but I was pleasantly surprised. Much of this DVD is comprised of archive footage and early 1990's documentary-style film-making, so don't expect HD  and Widescreen. You can, however, expect a beautifully nostalgic look back at the early days of Indian Motorcycle Company and its various luminaries. I'm a Harley guy, but I've always been intrigued by Indian. Timothy Cataldo, primarily through interviews with colorful old characters, captures the magic that drew so many to ride these fascinating machines.
This is an awsome video. They didn't leave anything out!
Interesting interviews of Indian motorcycle owners and mechanics.
Great DVD Love it- packed and shipped right on Thanks!
Pleased with purchase.
